timeline.message:
Boost to Loom 0.5
Add null related annotations

timeline.bodyText: am I the only one who likes to sort their annotations from shortest to largest? even intellij defaults to reverse order and it makes me iritat
timeline.author: Devan-Kerman

timeline.message:
Merge branch '1.16' of https://github.com/FabricMC/fabric into 1.16-nullification

# Conflicts:
#	build.gradle
#	fabric-rendering-v1/src/main/java/net/fabricmc/fabric/api/client/rendering/v1/BuiltinItemRendererRegistry.java
#	fabric-rendering-v1/src/main/java/net/fabricmc/fabric/impl/client/rendering/BuiltinItemRendererRegistryImpl.java

timeline.bodyText: Is this really needed since the parameter is a primitive (int)?
timeline.author: NinjaPhenix

replies.bodyText:
If it was important enough to address in the JD, the anno is warranted.
Null int is 0, so maybe that is a better boundary to use? I don't know the details of the rendering API well enough to say.
replies.author: dexman545

timeline.author: NinjaPhenix
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -167,7 +169,7 @@ public static void registerBreakByTool(Block block, Tag<Item> tag, int miningLev
 	/**
 	 * Hook for ItemStack.isEffectiveOn and similar methods.
 	 */
-	//TODO: nullable on user once we have an official @Nullable annotation in

timeline.bodyText: @NotNull on ItemConvertible and DynamicItemRenderer might be better than a @Contract annotation.
timeline.author: NinjaPhenix
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -76,6 +78,7 @@
 	 * @throws IllegalArgumentException if the item already has a registered renderer
 	 * @throws NullPointerException if either the item or the renderer is null
 	 */
+	@Contract("null, _ -> fail; _, null -> fail")
